posts.name: Yuval Gur | Electronics & Software mentor
posts.cooked:
Our group is using CANivore this year to split the CANbus circuits of the Swerve and the rest of the robot. We encountered a problem - every once in a while when we turn on the robot, the CANivore does not connect to RoboRIO and does not open a CAN circuit, which disconnects the swerve motors and disables the robot’s movment. The LEDs of the CANivore indicate that it is disconnected (blinking red), but there is no phisical disconection and it works as usual if you turn the robot power off and on again.

I am asking for your help in two aspects:

Is the problem known? Does anyone know how to prevent it?

Is it possible to detect the disconnection of the CAN devices programmatically and warn the drivers before the game starts?

Just to clarify the severity of the problem, here’s a game where this happened, we didn’t move ( # 2231 ) and lost as a result. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ulxMxTqxvtk

posts.name: klhutchi
posts.cooked: How are you powering the CANivore? We faced a similar issue when powering through the VRM. Switched it to a port on the PDH and haven’t seen that issue again.

posts.name: Jakob Wittry
posts.cooked:
We experienced the same issue at FIT District Waco Event in match 34.

As far as what we are doing to prevent it, the connection of the CANivore to the RoboRIO happens in the first few seconds after the RoboRIO boots, so we have been staying on the field until we see the status light on the CANivore turn green, and press the restart button on the RoboRIO if the CANivore status continues to indicate that it is disconnected. In a case where we do not notice the issue until the match starts, our current plan is to restart RoboRIO from the Driver Station application.

Additionally, we have switched our USB cable between the two devices and have not seen the issue again, although we have not done enough testing definitively to say if that helped with the issue.

In our case, we were already powering the CANivore directly from the PDH.

posts.name: Yuval Gur | Electronics & Software mentor
posts.cooked:
We indeed use VRM to power the CANivore. Thank you for the advice!

Which Breaker did you connect the CANivore to on the PDH?

posts.name: Omar Zrien CTR-Electronics Co-owner
posts.cooked:
Confirming healthy LEDs on the CANivore before starting the match is generally good advice, same as confirming your USB gamepads are working in the DS.

BUT you shouldn’t be having issues with your CANivore.  I recommend reaching out to our support .  We might want your DS logs, or learn more about your setup.

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: As one of the CSAs who will be at District 4, give us a shout if you haven’t gotten the problem fixed by then. I’d be happy to take a look in person
